column1: Bogotá was founded as the capital of the New Kingdom of Granada on 6 August 1538
column2: by Spanish conquistador Gonzalo Jiménez de Quesada after a harsh expedition into the Andes conquering the Muisca. The Muisca were the indigenous inhabitants of the region
column3: and they called the place of the foundation "Thybzaca" or "Old Town". The name of Bogotá corresponds to the Spanish pronunciation of the Chibcha Bacatá (or Mueketá) which was the name of a neighboring settlement located between the modern towns of Funza and Cota. There are different opinions about the meaning of the word Bacatá
column4: the most accepted being that it means "walling of the farmland" in the Chibcha language. Another popular translation argues that it means "The Lady of the Andes". Further
column5: the word 'Andes' in the Aymara language means "shining mountain"
column6: thus rendering the full lexical signification of Bogotá as "The Lady of the shining mountain" (notice
column7: however
column8: that the language of the Muisca people was not Aymara but Chibcha). Others suggest that Bacatá was the name of the Muisca cacique who governed the land before the Spaniards arrived. Jiménez de Quesada gave the settlement the name of "Our Lady of Hope" but the Spanish crown gave it the name of Santafé (Holy Faith) in 1540 when it was appointed as a city.Santafé became the seat of the government of the Spanish Royal Audiencia of the New Kingdom of Granada (created in 1550)
column9: and then after 1717 it was the capital of the Viceroyalty of New Granada. After the Battle of Boyacá on 7 August 1819
column10: Bogotá became the capital of the independent nation of Gran Colombia. It was Simón Bolívar who rebaptized the city with the name of Bogotá
column11: as a way of honoring the Muisca people and as an emancipation act towards the Spanish crown. Hence
column12: since the Viceroyalty of New Granada's independence from the Spanish Empire and during the formation of present-day Colombia
column13: Bogotá has remained the capital of this territory.

column1: Political unease over the Spanish monarchy and the rights of citizens born in the Americas had been feeling all over Spanish colonies in America
column2: and it was expressed in New Granada in many different ways
column3: accelerating the movement to independence. One of the most transcendent was the Insurrection of the Comuneros

column10: who was deeply impressed by both the insurrection and the execution. Nariño went on to become a politician in Santafé
column11: and he became acquainted with the liberal ideas in vogue in Europe. He started organizing clandestine meetings with other intellectuals and politicians to discuss and promote the independence of the American colonies from the Spanish crown. In 1794
column12: Nariño clandestinely translated and published in Santa Fe the Declaration of the Rights of Men and of the Citizen
column13: and copies of his translation were distributed all over the continent and started creating a stirring in the political mentalities of the time. The Spanish government had banned the distribution of the pamphlet and soon discovered the material and burned any copy that they could find. Nariño was arrested on 29 August 1794

column1: The period between 1810 and 1816 was marked by intense conflict between federalist and centralist factions over the nature of the new government of the recently emancipated juntas
column2: a period that has become known as la Patria Boba. The Province of Santafé became the Free and Independent State of Cundinamarca
column3: which soon became embroiled in a civil war against other of the local juntas which banded together to form the United Provinces of New Granada and advocated for a federalist government system. Following a failed military campaign against Quito
column4: General Simón Bolívar of the United Provinces led a campaign that led to the surrender of the Cundinamarca province in December 1814.

column2: the war had ended and the Spanish monarchy was restored on 11 December 1813. King Ferdinand VII of Spain declared the uprisings in the colonies illegal and sent a large army to quell the rebellions and reconquer the lost colonies
column3: for which he appointed General Pablo Morillo. Morillo led a successful military campaign that culminated in the capture of Santafé on 6 May 1816.

column1: Bogotá's growth has placed a strain on its roads and highways

column1: The TransMilenio system was created during Enrique Peñalosa's mayoral term

column3: bringing passengers to the main grid. TransMilenio's main routes are: Caracas Avenue
column4: Northern Highway (Autopista Norte)

column1: Bogotá's main airport is El Dorado International Airport

column7: the system suffered heavy damage and was forced to close. The economic effects of the subsequent civil war that followed prevented the damage from being repaired. Parts of the system continued to operate in a reduced state until 1951

column9: but exposed tracks can still be seen on many of the older roads of the city

column3: the city has been predominantly Roman Catholic. Proof of this religious tradition is the number of churches built in the historic city center. The city has been seat of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Bogotá since 22 March 1564. The seat of the Archbishop is the Primatial Cathedral of Bogotá; the archdiocese itself is located in new buildings in the north of the city. column1: Typical dishes of Bogotá include the ajiaco
column2: a soup prepared with chicken
column3: a variety of potatoes
column4: corn on the cob
column5: and guascas (an herb)
column6: usually served with sour cream and capers
column7: and accompanied by avocado and rice.

column1: Tamale is a very traditional Bogotá dish. Colombian tamal is a paste made with rice
column2: beef
column3: pork and/or chicken (depending on the region)
column4: chickpea
column5: carrot
column7: wrapped in plantain leaves and steam-cooked.

column2: strawberries with cream
column3: postre de natas and cuajada con melao are some of the main desserts offered in the city. Canelazo is a hot drink from the Altiplano prepared with aguapanela
column4: cinnamon and aguardiente. Another hot beverage is the carajillo
column5: made with coffee (tinto as it is known in Colombia) and aguardiente.

column3: plays
column4: movies

column1: Simón Bolívar Metropolitan Park is a large park regularly used to stage free concerts (such as the annual Rock al Parque festival).
The public Parque Nacional (National Park) has green spaces
column2: ponds
column3: games for children
column4: foot and bicycle paths
column5: and venues for entertainment such as public screenings of movies and concerts and events organized by the Council of Bogotá

column1: The Bogotá Botanical Garden (Jardín Botánico de Bogotá)
Parque de la 93 has day-time leisure activities and nightlife. Several of the top restaurants and bars in the city are in this park
column2: the park is known around the world like the Colombian Pike Place by having the first Starbucks in all the country and Carl's Jr. as well.

column3: a petting zoo
column4: and the "cerdodromo"

gardens

column1: Maloka is an interactive museum of sciences
Tourist train is a sightseeing train
column2: popular with Bogotá residents
column3: which runs to outlying towns Zipaquirá
column4: Cajicá and Nemocón along the lines of the former Bogotá Savannah Railway on weekends. The route to Zipaquirá (known for its salt cathedral) is 53 kilometres (33 miles) long. Another line goes towards the north for 47 km (29 mi) and ends at Briceño.

column1: The Usaquén Park is another of the most important parks in the city several of the best restaurants in this city are located there

column4: jugglers

column1: The District Institute for Recreation and Sport promotes recreation
column2: sports and use of the parks in Bogotá.

column1: Football has been declared a symbol of Bogotá
column2: and is widely played in the city. There are three professional clubs in the city
column3: Santa Fe
column4: Millonarios
column5: and La Equidad. The main stadium in the city is The Campín Stadium (Estadio Nemesio Camacho El Campín) home of the local teams Santa Fe and Millonarios
column6: In 2001 The Campín Stadium has been the place for the 2001 Copa América final between the Colombia national football and the Mexico national football
column7: final score 1–0 in favor of the home team and finally getting their first continental cup. The other soccer venue is the multi-use Techo Metropolitan Stadium which is the home of La Equidad.

column1: Other major sporting venues are the covered Coliseum El Campín
column2: the Simón Bolívar Aquatic Complex
column3: the Sports Palace
column4: the El Salitre Sports Venue which includes the Luis Carlos Galán Velodrome (which hosted the 1995 UCI Track Cycling World Championships)
column5: the El Salitre Diamond Ballpark and the BMX track "Mario Andrés Soto".

column1: The flag originated with the insurgency movement against the colonial authorities which began on 20 July 1810
column2: during which the rebels wore armbands with yellow and red bands
column3: as these colours were those of the Spanish flag used as the flag for the New Kingdom of Granada.On 9 October 1952
column4: exactly 142 years after these events
column5: decree 555 of 1952 officially adopted the patriotic armband as the flag of Bogotá. The flag of Cundinamarca follows the same pattern
column6: plus a light blue tile which represents the Virgin Mary's cape.

column1: The flag itself is a yellow band above a red one. The yellow denotes the gold from the earth
column2: as well as the virtues of justice
column3: clemency
column4: benevolence
column5: the so-called "mundane qualities" (defined as nobility
column7: richness
column8: generosity
column9: splendour
column10: health
column11: steadfastness
column12: joy and prosperity)
column13: long life
column15: power and constancy. The red denotes the virtue of charity
column16: as well as the qualities of bravery
column22: Colombians call it the blood of their people.The coat of arms of the city was granted by emperor Charles V (Charles I of Spain) to the New Kingdom of Granada
column23: by royal decree given in Valladolid
column24: Spain on 3 December 1548. It contains a black eagle in the center
column25: which symbolises steadfastness. The eagle is also a symbol of the Habsburgs
column26: which was the ruling family of the Spanish empire at the time. The eagle is crowned with gold and holds a red pomegranate inside a golden background. The border contains olive branches with nine golden pomegranates on a blue background. The two red pomegranates symbolize audacity
column27: and the nine golden ones represent the nine states which constituted the New Kingdom of Granada at the time. In 1932 the coat of arms was officially recognized and adopted as the symbol of Bogotá.Bogotá's anthem lyrics were written by Pedro Medina Avendaño; the melody was composed by Roberto Pineda Duque. The song was officially declared the anthem by decree 1000 31 July 1974
